issues.description: The problem statement instructs students to initialize both SealSaloon attributes (orders and stock) to default values in the SealSaloon constructor (e.g., "These should be initialized to default values ... in the constructor of SealSaloon"), but also explicitly requires that the stock attribute be static ("The following methods and attributes must be static: - stock attribute"). Initializing a static final field in an instance constructor is incorrect (static final fields must be initialized at declaration or in a static initializer). This is a structural contradiction that will confuse students about where/how to create/initialize the shared stock.
issues.suggested_fix: Resolve the static/initialization contradiction in the problem statement. Either: (A) Make the problem specify that stock is a static (class) field and should be initialized at declaration or in a static initializer (not in the instance constructor), or (B) require stock to be an instance (non-static) final field and instruct students to initialize it in the constructor. Update the text and UML accordingly so students have a single, consistent instruction for how to declare and initialize stock.

issues.description: The UML in the problem statement shows the SealSaloon attribute totalOrders typed as int, but the solution implementation declares totalOrders as long. This is a type mismatch between the specification and the reference implementation which could confuse students about the intended type for this field and its getter.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the type of totalOrders consistent across artifacts. Either change the UML and problem text to specify totalOrders as long (to match the solution), or change the solution implementation to use int (to match the UML). Update any wording that refers to totalOrders' type so students clearly know which primitive to use.
